displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We’re also starting a study probably not for a few months yet though. We’ve had two patients now who got testosterone. They both responded to testosterone but we then put them on something for the immune therapies, just not a trial, just hit or miss. And both of those two patients had incredible response to immune therapy. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So they started like negative something, so we’re going to try a trial where we are going to prime the cancer. Not actually treat it just to get the cancer you know. We think the testosterone potentially changes the cancer, the DNA of the cancer, and maybe that makes the cancer more recognizable by the immune system. So that’s- Patient: so it would somebody who just had the- Doctor: The trial is to get testosterone for three doses and then get immune therapy. Family Member: Well you couldn’t just do that as, like say you try it on those two guys, don’t you just try that with B__, knowing that there is still Germany, but um-? Doctor: Possibly. I have to figure how to get the immune therapy because it’s not an improved thing. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So there’s just some hoops to jump through. Family Member: Well, we’re kind of there now. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively.

Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: right now Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and we ain’t in the hospital. Doctor: Okay. Patient: What would you do to accommodate me with the seizure other than dialing nine one one?

Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And can you get it up there? Patient: I’ll get it from C___. Doctor: Okay. Do you need a script from me? Patient: Yeah, I better. Doctor: Okay. That way it’s a reminder that you need to go get that. Patient: In three months I’ll get another CAT scan? Doctor: Yes. Patient: But not bone scan? Doctor: No I don’t think we need it unless anything changes with your surgery and all the symptoms – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and of course if any of that changes, don’t wait the three months. I need to know before that of course.

Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: …you know whatever that end date is and it probably should have been your last infusion if we’re gonna.. Patient: It probably will be and I mean I Doctor: Yeah. Patient: think that the decision point, I see him a week from today. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay . Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success.

Patient: I mean it’s. Doctor: It’s worth the, let’s, let’s try it. Patient: Okay. I, I you know and according to my survey you know I mean it’s a decision we have to make together. You know? Doctor: It is. Patient: And I think I ask a lot of questions. Doctor: No. I think you do. Absolutely. Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: these three, four, five, six session of chemo – Doctor: Um, hmm. Patient: - what would be the best result in your opinion? Doctor: Well that you feel better, the PSA goes down to zero and the next imaging scans are rock stable. That’d be a homerun. It won’t ever really go away you know these things don’t change. Patient: The metastatic areas we see on the bones… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone?

Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now. Doctor: And there are many other ones in development, which I explained. Family Member: So are we not working towards cure are we working towards remission? Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Absolutely. And again, some of these remissions are very long-lasting. Healthcare Professional: And there are people who go on hormone therapy and don’t need a second-line hormone. Like they’re in remission for fifteen years. Now he’s telling you an average but we see people who don’t need another therapy you know for many, many years. So you know it’s, you know again, I mean we don’t worry about fall –

Family Member: Yeah, that’s what it is Healthcare Professional: Breaking bad news Doctor: Yes, yes, I thought he meant Breaking Bad like the TV Family Member: Yeah, that's what I’m thinking Healthcare Professional: No, No Doctor: I’m, like, did J___ do something I’m not aware of? (laughter) Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that.

Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: C___ Doctor: So you can actually go to G____. Patient: Okay, perfect. Family Member: Oh wow! Doctor: I’m sure G____has a machine. Family Member: And they do as good a job to here? Doctor: Oh yeah, same people, same machines. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Follow-up question here to Doctor: You could do either way. Family Member: Yeah. And how long are you there when you go get your radiation? Doctor: About a half an hour total. So you do it on your way to work or on the way home. Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes?

Patient: No he said it was come - I think he said it was come three times, twice, twice a month. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Something like that. Doctor: Oh I see. Okay. Patient: See he says three… Doctor: Okay so not uh. Now the other possibility is of diarrhea. So you know if you do have it we’ll need to control it, give you lomotil, give you medication to help control Patient: Okay. Doctor: it as soon as possible. Okay but the chances of that happening are very small. The biggest thing is the second chemotherapy doesn’t have any danger to the nerves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like this one. Because this one that’s why I worry that you’re getting ten, twelve cycles now is your – are your nerves gonna start showing tingling, numbness, things like that? Patient: Yeah cuz see Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …my feet the most yeah…

Family Member: He has tears in his eyes because he wants to be the man. And God is the man. He puts whoever in the position has to do whatever they have to do. Doctor: Yeah Family Member: But the fact is we’re able to do it. It doesn’t matter which pocket it comes. Patient: Well I wasn’t out there. So I’m glad I wasn’t out there. DOC Doctor: Well that was not appropriate. Family Member: And the point is in situations like that you can’t join a group, you can’t join a crowd, you have to stand out in a separate entity and say well I’m not gonna stoop to their level but I’m not gonna be stupid either. Doctor: Yeah so if are issues along the way – Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Oh, that’s at home. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s still a lot of paperwork if you fall. Just don’t call the clinic. Less paperwork. Yeah. Because then I have to deal with it, and so, yeah, let’s not follow through. Family Member: Less paperwork. Patient: Um. Doctor: Good questions. Man. Patient: Also, some neurologist thing, you know, but, syncope. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: He told me to start weaning off from the tamoxifen. Patient: And that stuff is nasty to get off from. Doctor: Go slow. Patient: Yeah. That’s right. So I don’t know if that’s going to effect- Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Okay so Patient: Good. Doctor: Okay so there is no new areas. The lung, liver, everything is completely clear. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: The lymph nodes, you know the only change we see is one lymph node in the abdomen that has gone from six millimeter to eight millimeter which I think even if I measured it an hour apart I might come up with – Patient: Right. Doctor: that much of a difference. So… Family Member: Is that the only lymph node involved? Doctor: That’s visible right now. Family Member: Oh, okay. So that’s the same one that’s been there? Doctor: Previously, before we started, I think there were more than one that we were seeing.
